text: Special report number 239 coming in 3, 2, 1. From Washington, D.C., a special report on our nation's spaceflight participant program. A program that may allow you, an ordinary citizen, to someday fly in space. If we take time to reflect on those people in our lives who have had the greatest influence, For most of us, somewhere near the top is a teacher. NASA thinks teachers are important people too. Schools and teachers are training the nation's greatest resource, our children. With this in mind, it was no surprise that the President, at NASA's recommendation, requested NASA to select a teacher as the first civilian to fly into space. Here to tell us about this program is Patrick Templeton, Associate Administrator for External Relations at NASA Headquarters. By flying a teacher, we will be able to share with a very large segment of society the excitement of the space program and bring it into classrooms, bring it into the homes through the teacher and the student. And what really, what better mechanism to communicate with the American public than through our wonderful teachers? because, by bringing the message of the space program into the classroom, and that's conceivably every elementary and secondary school classroom in this country, we will excite the imagination and the interest that those youngsters already have in the space program, excite their interest further, bring the space program closer to them, help weave, in some respects, the theme of space through their curriculum and help make it a little bit more exciting because every discipline, whether it's reading, writing, or arithmetic, has some application to space. And if we can bring a little bit more of that excitement into the classroom, it could help interest these youngsters into studying, as they grow older, more science, math, getting into engineering, and not be intimidated by it. So we believe that by flying a teacher in space, we're going to be able to communicate that message out to an awful lot more young people and to their parents than we might have by flying someone else first. Right now, the United States is the world leader in aeronautics and space technologies. That lead, however, is shrinking as other nations apply themselves to these areas. If this country is going to stay ahead in the world, we'll stay ahead in new technology development, stay ahead in industry, and new product developments, then we have to be very well-versed in high technology. This emphasis now on science, math, engineering, and problem-solving is very, very important. The space program and the flying of a teacher can help bring that a little closer to home, and bringing it into the classroom, I think, by flying a teacher, and by bringing that awareness into the elementary and secondary school levels. Because if we don't graduate more people, more youngsters in the future who have this capability, then our friends in foreign countries who are emphasizing these kinds of studies will get ahead of us. And the new jobs that will be created in the future. More of those will be created abroad than are created here, and the jobs for our children and their children will not be as many as we would like and as we should have to maintain our standard of living. So this is a very important step toward helping bring that awareness closer to home. An announcement of opportunity issued in October lists the specific qualifications and requirements for applications. And that process application process will probably run through January. We are in the process now of selecting a procedure to evaluate the applications and we hope that that will be through that process in time to bring the hundred or so finalists to from each state and the territories and so forth to the Johnson Space Center for a workshop for about a week and then coming back and selecting out of those hundred, hundred and ten semi-finalists, ten finalists, we will be taking that down to five and then selecting a primary and a backup. And those two will go through an eight-week training at the Johnson Space Center to prepare them for flight. And the backup obviously will be there in the event that something happens to the primary candidate. Program manager for the space flight participant program in the office of space flight is Alan Ladwig. We've actually been looking at the situation on how to fly private citizen on the space shuttle for the past 12 years ever since the development on the vehicle began. There had been several task forces that have looked at that over the years. And then in early 1982, NASA administrator James Beggs asked the NASA Advisory Council to set up a task force and look into specifically how could we include private citizens on shuttle missions. During the work of the task force, they interviewed a lot of different people, different organizations, and they addressed it from two tracks. One, to fly individuals that were very well-known, celebrity-type of people. The other track included categories. The task force decided that the best way to go about doing this was to choose categories. and in that they discovered that we should go with a communicator of some type because that fit within NASA's mandates under the Space Act. And two mandates in particular were the mandate to widely disseminate information about the shuttle program to the public, and secondly, to foster and maintain U.S. leadership in aeronautic and astronaut research. Mr. Ladwig spelled out for us some of the requirements. The teachers that are eligible for this first opportunity have to come from the elementary or secondary education level. They have to be full-time teachers, they have to be U.S. citizens, and they can't be married to a current or former NASA employee. What we're going to expect of them is to complete an application packet, and as part of that packet, we're going to ask them to complete an essay question that states, why do they want to go on this mission, what would they do during the flight opportunity, and how would they share the experience when they get back. So we're going to expect a pretty big commitment from them to work with NASA for about one year after they come back to go out and talk to civic groups, to student groups, to work with other teachers, to be involved in teacher workshops, plus whatever it is they are going to recommend that they can do. So we want teachers to understand that this is a pretty big commitment. It's more than just going up and having a nice flight and coming back. we're gonna expect them to work pretty hard for us. So, again, this is why we need a good communicator. Somebody that is a little shy in front of groups or doesn't like to talk in front of groups probably won't do very well in this program. Because the space shuttle provides an almost airliner-like atmosphere for its passengers, it will not require a person of above-average physical health to qualify. The medical standards for a spaceflight participant are probably the most lenient standards that we've ever had for a person to fly on a space mission. If the candidate is in reasonably good health, has no physical injuries or diseases that would get in the way of their participating during a mission in getting off the shuttle in case of an emergency, that's one standard. The second standard is that their vision has to be correctable to 2040 and better eye. They're hearing, they have to be able to hear a whispered voice at three feet, and they can even wear a hearing aid, and their blood pressure has to be below 160 over 100, so that's a pretty lenient set of standards, and most people that are in reasonably good health shouldn't have a hard time with that. When the person comes back and works for NASA for that year, we will be asking them to go on sabbatical from their school for that time period, And NASA will reimburse the school system for their salary, plus pick up their travel and expenses that are incurred during that time. Choosing a teacher as its first spaceflight participant is not directed solely toward education. There are, however, several programs that are. Through the Space Shuttle Program, there are several opportunities for the education community. First of all, we have the Shuttle Student Involvement Project, which has just begun its fifth competition. We began that in the academic year of 1980-81, where we selected ten student winners from across the country who submitted experiment ideas to be flown on the shuttle. Since that time, we've selected a total of 50 students. When the student is announced as a winner, we match them up with a corporate sponsor who helps the student turn their winning proposal into a flight-ready experiment. Now, we have flown approximately ten of those experiments to date, And our intention is to fly at least one shuttle student involvement project on each mission. Another good opportunity is available through the getaway special program or our small self-contained payload program. And through that program, any citizen who has, or anybody around the world for that matter, who has a valid experiment idea that they would like to conduct in space can purchase space on a getaway special, And that can be as little as $3,000 or up to $10,000 depending on the amount of space and weight that you want to purchase. And we have over 500 reservations for getaway specials at this time. We have flown approximately 21 of those on missions so far. And again, that's the type of thing where they're flown on a space-available basis. We might fly four or five on one mission, 12 on the next, whatever the space is. About 40% of the getaway specials have been sold to educational institutions anywhere from high school students to college students to graduate students. A more recent program is Operation Lift Off, which is a initiative that's mainly directed at the elementary schools the 75,000 elementary schools around the country where we are fortifying our efforts through educational publications, videodisc, videotapes that are available for classroom use. This supplements the ongoing effort we've already had at the secondary level, and is going to include a whole range of new opportunities and programs. As part of that, you may have heard of the Young Astronaut Program, which will be a new club geared to students anywhere from the age of approximately nine up to perhaps 16 or 17, and that is being spearheaded by the National Space Institute, which is a private space advocacy organization that is that's going to seek private sector funding to initiate these clubs around the country. NASA is working with our education system in cooperation and partnership with the private sector to help keep the U.S. a leader in science and technology. I think as we start to fly private citizens on the shuttle, it's likely to change the whole way people think about space flight and the whole space revolution that's going on. As you said in the past, the main way people participated has been by watching it on TV. Now we're going to have these opportunities, limited though they may be in the beginning, for a private citizen to actually be a part of all that. We believe that the excitement that is going to cause, the motivation this is going to create for people is going to lead to new levels of excellence and a new sense of inspiration for particularly students in the case of educators and among other people as we select different categories. We've already received indications from teachers around the country that this initial opportunity of just mentioning that teachers might be able to go or that a teacher will go as our first participant has created excitement in the classroom. Teachers are getting more pumped up about their own occupation. Students are getting excited because they're now looking at teachers as a new role model, as somebody that might be flying. And we think that with all the ideas that can be generated about what a teacher can do up there, what they're going to do when they get back, that the excitement caused by having that when we name two winners per state so that we're going to have state ambassadors out of this as well, who will also go out and speak on our behalf, we think this is going to totally change the way people think about the space program. NASA believes that through the spaceflight participant program in general and picking an educator in particular for this first opportunity is going to motivate students to pay a little more attention to their science and technology courses. We have seen through various national commissions and different studies that have occurred over the past eight years that the U.S. does have a problem in science and math literacy throughout the country with young people. We believe that the spaceflight participant program can make a contribution towards solving that problem by encouraging students to study science and math a little more closely and they will start to find out how the space program is tied directly into their interest and field of endeavor that they might pursue that may not even be directly associated with a science or math career. This has been a special report in our nation's Spaceflight Participant Program brought to you by NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. with sentiments, theigglyحمs.org station. Here we go. I'm going to work to work on your own. You can do that.

And that can be as little as $3,000 or up to $10,000 depending on the amount of space and weight that you want to purchase.

students.

anywhere from the age of approximately nine up to perhaps 16 or 17, and that is being spearheaded

that's going to seek private sector funding to initiate these clubs around the country.

on.
